article_title: Suhr’s biggest enemy turned out to be his City Hall ‘friends’
article_text:
Suhr’s biggest enemy turned out to be his City Hall ‘friends’

Photo: Lance Iversen, The Chronicle Mayor Ed Lee (left) and Greg Suhr on the day in April 2011 when Lee...

San Francisco needs someone who can reform the Police Department. To do that, we’ll have to find someone who can stand up to City Hall.

article_metadata.sailthru.author: By Willie Brown
article_metadata.description: Suhr’s biggest enemy turned out to be his City Hall ‘friends’  The city needs to turn inward and look honestly at what brought us to the point where Greg Suhr, the most progressive, respected and  beloved of all the chiefs I’ve known, was unable to change the SFPD — or the city policies that govern the department.  Suhr tried, but he wound up standing alone, waiting for that group over at City Hall to join him.  Nice line, but TV crews don’t need armed guards for protection when they sit down with Trump.  The entrance of state Treasurer John Chiang into the 2018 governor’s race spells trouble for Lt. Gov. Gavin Newsom.  Newsom has been raising money like crazy for months, in part out of concern that a billionaire like Tom Steyer or someone well known like former Los Angeles Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa would get into the race.  [...] he has to hope that someone like that really does jump in.  Because if it’s Newsom vs.  [...] getting past 50 percent in a one-on-one in November could be tough if he’s running against a Democrat who can appeal to Republicans.  [...] would Villaraigosa, a hard-core Democrat from a hard-core Democratic city.  [...] Chiang, with his no-drama background as the state’s treasurer and onetime member of the Board of Equalization, could be that guy.  Former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani was in town the other day to give a talk about business security at the Bay Area Council’s annual economic forum.  The table talk was that if Donald Trump is elected president, Giuliani would be on the short list to head Homeland Security.  [...] through the window I could see that while the bar was packed with people watching the TV, the dining room was completely empty.  “Mr. Brown, I know you’re one of our best customers, but tonight we are completely booked,” the host said.  Julia Roberts is great as the director of a stock-picker TV show, and George Clooney is just as good as the Jim Cramer-type star who does the picking.  When one of his picks costs the little people a ton of money, a little person played by Jack O’Connell barges on air to demand justice.  If you plan on visiting the redone SFMOMA, I suggest you carve out at least a half a day.  There’s one painting that has already emerged as the crowd favorite, with everyone lining up to take selfies in front of it.
article_metadata.author.name: By Willie Brown
